A B S T R A C T
Designing highly optical active photocatalytic heterojunctions with multi-pronged capabilities for environmental applications is still a challenge. In this work the photocatalytic potential of Ag2CrO4/Ag/BiFeO3@RGO was systematically tested via photo-reduction of BrO3−, degradation of Ciprofloxacin (CIF) and photo-reduction of CO2 under broad light spectrum. Among various samples ABR-8 exhibits 99.6% BrO3− photoreduction and 96.3% CIF photo-oxidation in 90min (nearly 96% in 60min). ABR-11 (with 11wt% RGO) selectively generates 180 μmol g−1 of CH4 in 8 h under visible light (260 μmol g−1 under alkali activation) which is approximately 60 times than bare BiFeO3. The excellent performance of ABR series is attributed to successful formation of Zscheme which assists in efficient charge transfer, reduced recombination and wide spectrum response. In addition the electron donation-mediation of plasmonic Ag0 and adsorption-electron mediation of reduced graphene oxide has a triggering effect on reductive and oxidative capabilities. The band structure analysis, scavenging experiments and electron spin resonance studies make it possible to predict a suitable mechanism for bromate reduction, CIF degradation and CH4 generation. sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
In the recent decades, mankind and ecosystem have been suffering through severe environmental pollution problems, climate change and energy crisis. The ubiquitous problems of resource depletion and exposure to toxins have worsened in developing economies because of huge industrial revolution and poor monitoring & control policies. To meet pollution remediation and energy challenges, demands for clean energy technologies utilizing renewable energy have increased [1–3]. Semiconductor photocatalysis have been explored and utilized as most promising techniques for mineralizing toxic pollutants [4–6] and energy or fuel production [7,8]. However advances and novel developments are required to tackle the ever-increasing types of pollutants and utilizing photocatalysis for practical energy applications. Among various emerging pollutants in water system, antibiotics have been creating problems [9] because of their growing consumption and continuous presence in water bodies beyond permissible limits [10]. In addition microorganisms are developing resistance for antibiotics due to continuous exposure which intensifies the risks and hazards [11,12]. Ciprofloxacin (CIF) has been broadly utilized as a critical fluoroquinolones anti-microbial for treatment of both human and animal diseases and has been detected in drinking water supplies [13]. During various purification treatments various by-products as bromate (BrO3−) are produced and have received expanding consideration because of its cancer-causing and mutagenic nature detailed by the International Agency for Research on Cancer [14]. The World Health Organisation has restricted safe bromate concentration to 10 mgL−1 in drinking water but around the world 0.4–60mg L−1 have been detected [15]. One of another major environmental issue is energy production by solar energy and efficient conversion of green-house gases as feedstock to produce fuels such as methane, methanol and syn gas. The solar reduction of CO2 into organic fuels promises to address environmental as well as clean energy issues simultaneously [16,17]. But CO2 reduction involves cleavage of C-O bond and formation of C-H bond which is difficult to achieve under mild conditions. However photocatalytic reduction of CO2 is favourable as it lowers the activation barrier. Thermodynamics suggest that redox potential for CH4 formation is −0.24 eV vs NHE which is more favourable than CO (-0.42 eV). But kinetically CH4/CO2 is an 8e−/8H+ reaction and is less favoured to CO/CO2 (2e−/2H+) reaction [18]. Secondly CO2 activation, charge separation and high life-time of carriers are major concerns in photoreduction. Selectivity is another issue as received multiple unwanted products may create another problem of disposal. Thus to address photocatalytic removal of emerging pollutants and energy production issues especially selectivity concern (in CO2 reduction), novel photocatalytic systems have to be designed via rational band gap engineering, optimization of synthetic and operational parameters and rational choice of suitable semiconductors. As popular strategy highly optically active hetero-junctions of semiconductors with different band structures [19,20] have been designed and fabricated for effective charge separation, spectral response and reduced recombination. Among various candidates for junctions with a wide spectrum response Ag based catalysts and composites such as with Ag3PO4 [21], Ag2WO4 [22], Ag2S [23], and Ag2CO3 [24], have been synthesized with proven excellent photocatalytic performances. Ag2CrO4 (ACO) is gaining popularity because of its low band gap, high optical absorption coefficient and unique electronic structure [25]. Because of surface
plasmon response of metallic Ag [26] extraordinary results are obtained in visible powered pollutant remediation and energy applications for so-called ordinary junctions [27]. In addition as other possible candidates perovskites and based materials have also been promising photocatalysts because of their unique electronic and crystal structure and low cost [28]. Among these BiFeO3 (BFO) is a perovskite type material with a small band gap of (2.2 eV) and tremendous chemical stability. It has received impressive consideration in recent decades because of its excellent photochemical stability and low cost [29,30]. Reduced graphene oxide (RGO) has found a special position among organic counterparts of junctions because of its higher electron mobility, stability and excellent conductivity [31,32]. It is generally used as support matrix or as electron mediator in the junctions [33]. Both ACO and BFO are highly visible active but suffer from high recombination. However forming a Z-scheme junction and using an electron mediator as Ag and RGO: Photo-reduction system (BFO), photo-oxidation system (ACO), electron donor and mediator under visible light (Metallic Ag) and adsorbent-cum support matrix-cum electron mediator (RGO), can be an interesting option. Hence these fascinating ideas inspired to couple ACO and BFO with a hierarchical structure to improve separation efficiency and optical response. Moreover during designing if some portion of Ag+ gets converted to Ag0 an interface of Ag+/Ag0 is formed which may have polarization effect. Both metallic Ag0 and RGO can shorten migration distance and increase life-time of charge carriers in addition to generation of charge carriers by SPR effect of Ag. Well defined and optimized junctions of Ag2CrO4/Ag/BiFeO3@RGO were thus fabricated and used for high performance BrO3− reduction, CIF degradation and selective CH4 photo-reduction. As per desired objectives the composite catalyst ABR shows brilliant performance for photo-reduction of BrO3− (99.6% in 60min), photo-degradation of CIF (96.2% in 90min) and selective CH4 evolution from CO2 (180 μmol g−1) under visible light. In addition the catalyst displays decent activity in NIR and natural solar light too. The apt positioning of the band edges and rational optimisation for the catalyst leads to higher formation of reactive oxygen species, increased charge separation and reduced recombination. In addition the triggering effect of metallic Ag and RGO leads to manifold increase in reaction rate and makes system promising in real situations.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: Potassium chromate (K2CrO4), silver nitrate (AgNO3), bismuth nitrate (Bi(NO3)3), ferric nitrate nonahydrate (Fe(NO3)3·9H2O), nitric acid (HNO3), triton X-100, graphite flakes, potassium permanganate (KMnO4), sodium hydroxide, L-ascorbic acid, potassium permanganate (KMnO4) were obtained from sigma Aldrich (AR grade) and used without any purification. Ciprofloxacin (CIF) (C17H18FN3O3,> 98% purity) was supplied by Sigma-Aldrich.

sections.heading: 2.2. Synthesis
sections.text:
Ag2CrO4 nanoparticles (ACO) were prepared according to previously reported method by precipitation of AgNO3 and K2CrO4 [34]. In a typical procedure bare BiFeO3 (BFO) was synthesized by reaction of 0.02mol of Bi(NO3)3·5H2O and Fe(NO3)3·9H2O with 20mL of 1M
HNO3 in ethyelene glycol (with Triton X-100 as surfactant). After continuous stirring for 1 h the contents were dried at 130 °C followed by treatment at 500 °C for 2 h [35]. Graphene oxide (GO) was obtained by typical chemical exfoliation of graphite powder using modified Hummers’ method [36]. L-ascorbic acid (300mg) and a suspension (300mL) of prepared GO (0.1mgmL−1) were mixed and stirred with progressive addition of NH3 solution to maintain pH between 9 and 10. The suspension was then subjected to 30min sonication with further heating to 100 °C for 2 h for formation of reduced graphene oxide (RGO). For synthesis of Ag2CrO4/BiFeO3 (ACO/BFO) junction, 0.1 g of BFO nanoparticles was dispersed in 20mL distilled water with 30min ultrasonic treatment. To this varying amounts of AgNO3 were added and stirred in dark for 1 h. A certain amount of K2CrO4 solution was added slowly into above solution with vigorous stirring for 6 h. The contents were separated, filtered and vacuum dried. For synthesizing of Ag2CrO4/Ag/BiFeO3 (AB) junction, to the suspension of AgNO3 and BFO aqueous K2CrO4 was added dropwise and stirred in dark for 4 h. The precipitates were then exposed to 500W Xe lamp (visible light) for half hour to convert some of Ag+ to Ag0. The solid product obtained was collected by centrifugation and washed with by ethanol and distilled water and finally dried at 60 °C for 24 h. In this way, different weight ratios (5%, 10% and 15%) of Ag/ACO to BFO were obtained and named as AB-5, AB-10 and AB-15 respectively. For synthesizing Ag2CrO4/Ag/BiFeO3@RGO (ABR) series, AB-10 was used to optimize ratio of RGO on basis of optical studies and preliminary photocatalytic experiments. To obtain ABR junction a known amount of RGO was suspended in distilled water and added to the synthetic procedure of AB before addition of K2CrO4. In this manner ABR with different weight ratios of RGO were obtained as ABR-5 (5%), ABR-8 (8%) and ABR-11 (8%). The synthesis scheme for ABR is represented graphically in Fig. 1.

sections.heading: 2.3. Materials characterization
sections.text: The crystal structure of single, binary and ternary photocatalysts was investigated using a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku, Japan) equipped with Cu Kα radiation. The surface morphologies were photographed using a Thermal field emission scanning electron microscope (SEM) (SU-70 Hitachi, Japan). The TEM images were obtained using Transmission electron microscopy (JEM1230 instrument, Japan). The elemental composition and binding energy positions were determined with monochromatic Al Kα X-rays (1485.5 eV) using K-Alpha+X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy system (Thermo Fisher Scientific, UK) operated at 10mA and 15 kV (4.5× 10−9 Torr pressure). The optical response was determined from UV–visible diffuse reflectance spectra (UV-DRS) procured from Hitachi U-4100 spectrophotometer with BaSO4 as reference. A Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument was used to quantify specific surface area by Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. Photoluminescence (PL) emission spectra of materials were measured by a FL F4500 instrument (Hitachi, Japan) spectrophotometer with excitation wavelength at 325 nm. The functional group and bonding determination was done using a Nicolet 5700 FTIR spectrophotometer by standard KBr pellet method. The intermediates of pollutant degradation were detected by a LCQ-Deca xp LC-MS instrument (Thermo) equipped with an electrospray ionization (EIS) source. Total organic carbon (TOC) of treated water was determined using a TOC analyzer (Shimadzu TOC-VCPH). The electron spin resonance (ESR) spectra of photo-generated free radicals (•O2– and •OH) trapped by 5,5-dimethyl-Lpyrroline N-oxide (DMPO) trapped were obtained on a Bruker ER200-SRC spectrometer.

sections.heading: 2.4. Photo-electrochemical studies
sections.text:
The electrochemical properties of single, binary and ternary catalysts were probed using a CHI 660D electrochemical workstation via a three electrode system which include Pt counter electrode, the working
electrode and Reference electrode (Ag/AgCl). For fabricating working electrode (e.g ABR/ITO), 5mg of material and 10 μL of aqueous Nafion were dispersed in ethanol and subjected to 30min sonication. This suspension was then dropped (dip-coating) onto indium-tin oxide (ITO) glass (1 cm×1.5 cm) and then placed in oven for 8 h at 100 °C for fabrication of composite working electrode. Electrochemical experiments were performed for photocatalysts with 0.05M Na2SO4 under the open-circuit potential and visible light by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). The AC voltage amplitude was 5.0 mV and frequency from 0.01 Hz to 100 kHz. The EIS spectrum was fitted into an equivalent circuit i.e a charge transfer resistance (RCT) of 80 Ω working in parallel with space charge capacitor as constant phase element (RSCC) and 20Ω electrolyte resistance (RS) in series. Photocurrent response experiment was performed using 0.5M Na2SO4 as electrolyte, and the irradiation area was 1 cm2 under 300W Xe lamp. The Mott-Schottky plots for measuring the flat band potentials of ACO and BFO photocatalysts were obtained from capacitance data. The same test system was used for Mott-Sckottky (MS) measurement but in the dark. The scan rate was 25mV/s and the scan frequency was 1 kHz.

sections.heading: 2.5. Photocatalytic experiments
sections.text: The photocatalytic potential of synthesized catalysts was tested by photoreduction of bromate ions, photo-degradation of pharmaceutical drug (as target pollutant) and photo-reduction of CO2 under wide spectrum of light. For artificial visible irradiation a 300W Xe lamp was used a 400 and 800 nm cut-off filters for visible (380–780 nm) and NIR light (> 780 nm) with approximate intensity of 450 and 220 mW cm−2 respectively in a glass photo-reactor (TOPTION photochemical reactor). The experiments were also performed under natural solar light and UV light (less than380 nm) using 300W Hg lamp (180 mW cm−2). The temperature was kept constant (30 ± 0.5 °C) through a water circulation system.

sections.heading: 2.5.1. Photo-reduction of bromate ions and degradation of ciprofloxacin
sections.text:
For photoreduction of bromate ions 30mg of photocatalyst was dispersed into 100mL aqueous solution of 500 μg L−1 BrO3− ions by sonication. The suspension was kept in dark for 20min and then exposed to light for photocatalytic reaction. The decrease in bromate ion concentration was monitored at regular intervals by analysing 3mL aliquots drawn from the reaction mixture. The aliquots were centrifuged and filtered through 0.22μ Teflon membrane filter and residual bromate ion concentration was analysed using ion chromatography utilizing a Dionex ICS-900 instrument (USA) with an AS-19 column and AS-40 auto-sampler. The experiments were performed in distilled water and tap water whose parameters are listed in Table 1. The degradation of CIF in presence of synthesized photocatalysts was also studied. In a typical experimental photocatalyst (0.2 g L−1) was dispersed in the CIF suspension (10mg L−1) and exposed to light source in photo-reactor. The sample cell was placed 15 cm away from light source and lamp was placed in cylindrical quartz arrangement. For photodegradation analysis, 20 μL aliquot from slurry was injected out, centrifuged and filtered using a Teflon syringe filter (0.22 μ). The concentration of CIF was measured after regular intervals of time by high performance liquid chromatography (SHIMADZU Japan) equipped with a C-18 column (15×4.6mm, 5 μm) and UV detector at 277 nm. The mobile phase used was 20% A (Acetonitrile) and 80% B (0.1 % formic acid) with 1mLmin−1 flow rate. The injection volume was 10 μL. The gradient was set with 15% B which increased to 35% and to 95% in 35min. The gradient then returned to initial composition. Mass spectrometry (MS) was done in+ ve ion mode using electro-spray ionization (ESI). The spray voltage was fixed at 5.5 keV and nebulization pressure was 35psi. To analyse the role of active radicals scavenging experiments were performed with1,4-benzoquinone (BQ), isopropanol (IPA) and ethylenediamminetetraacetic acid disodium salt (EDTA-2Na) were used as scavengers for •O2–, •OH and h+ respectively. sections.heading: 2.5.2. Photoreduction of CO2 with H2O
sections.text: The synthesized catalysts were also used for photoreduction of CO2 with H2O as reductant in a closed gas circulation reactor maintained at constant temperature (30 ± 0.5 °C). Photocatalytic CO2 reduction activity of the as-obtained catalysts was also tested under visible, UV, solar, and NIR light. The experiments were carried out in a gas closed circulation reactor system with a quartz window for exposure. 40mg of catalyst was dispersed by dip coating over a glass plate (3 cm2) placed on a holder in a pyrex reactor vessel. 40 mL of distilled water was then charged from the bottom. Prior to experiments the reactor was degassed and high purity CO2 gas (99.99%) was bubbled gradually till the pressure reaches 1 atm. The reactor was then exposed to light source (UV, visible, NIR or solar) for 8 h. The photogenerated Co and CH4 were detected and quantified with Agilent 7890A gas chromatograph which is equipped with methanator, thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and flame ionisation detector (FID) and Porapak Q packed column after each 1 h interval. The experiment was also conducted for enhanced results by alkali activation. The same experiment was repeated with 0.2M NaOH solution instead of distilled water.

sections.heading: 3.1. Photocatalyst characterization
sections.text:
The XRD patterns of BFO, ACO, Ag2CrO4/Ag/BiFeO3 (AB-10), Ag2CrO4/Ag/BiFeO3@RGO (ABR-8) and ABR-11 are shown in Fig. 2. BiFeO3 nano-flowers show diffraction peaks at 2θ=22.3°, 31.8°, 32.3°, 39.3°, 45.9°, 51.5°, 51.9°, 56.7° and 66.1° corresponding to (0 1 2),
(1 0 4), (1 1 0), (0 0 6), (0 2 4), (1 1 6), (1 2 2), (0 1 8) and (2 0 8) crystal planes respectively. These peaks can be indexed to typical rhombohedral perovskite structure of BFO with polar R3C space group well matched with JCPDS 86–1518 [37]. Ag2CrO4 exhibits characteristic peaks at 17.5°, 21.7°, 25.3°, 31.1°, 31.2°, 32.4°, 33.8°, 39.1°, 44.2°, 52.0°, 55.9°, and 57.2° for diffraction peaks of (0 2 0), (1 2 0), (0 1 3), (2 1 1), (0 0 2), (1 3 1), (1 2 2), (2 4 0), (4 0 0), (2 4 2), and (2 1 3) crystal planes respectively. This pattern corresponds to orthorhombic structure (JCPDS 26–0952) [38,39]. XRD pattern of Ag2CrO4/Ag/BiFeO3 (AB-10) (10 wt% ACO/Ag) shows the characteristic peaks of ACO and BFO along with diffraction peaks for metallic Ag0. Therefore, during syntheis of binary junction, the structure of both the catalysts is preserved, although the observed slight shift 2θ values as compared to bare materials refelt minor structural modifications owing to interactions between the two and conversion of some of Ag+ ions into metallic Ag. Simlarily in case of ABR-8 and ABR-11 the peaks associated with ACO and BFO are observed along with additional peaks for Ag0 and RGO. The peaks at 2θ angle at 23.8° and 42.8° correspond to (0 0 2) and (1 0 1) diffraction planes of RGO. The intensity of peaks for RGO is not high because of low content in the ternary junction. In addition Ag0 exhibits peaks at 38.2°, and 43.4° corresponfing to (1 1 1) and (2 0 0) planes respectively (JCPDS 65-2871) [40]. The XPS survey scan spectrum (Fig. S1) shows that APRB-8 contains Ag, Cr, O, Bi, Fe and N elements which indicates the formation of junction between ACO, BFO and RGO. Fig. 3(a) shows ag 3d XPS spectrum with deconvoluted peaks at 368.2 and 374.2 eV corresponding to Ag 3d3/2 and Ag 3d5/2 for Ag+ respectively. The split peaks at 368.7 and 374.6 eV correspond to metallic Ag0 [41]. The peak area shows that small amount of Ag+ has been converted to Ag0 on light exposure as per synthetic procedure. In case of Cr 2p spectrum, the two peaks at 577.1.7 eV and 589.2 eV can be attributed to Cr 2p3/2 and Cr 2p1/2, respectively demonstrating the presence of Cr6+ species for Ag2CrO4 [42]. The deconvoluted Bi XPS spectrum (Fig. 3c) shows two
peaks for Bi 4f7/2 and Bi 4f5/2 and orbitals located at 158.3 and 163.7 respectively. Fig. 3(d) shows two fitted peaks located at 710.5 and 724.4 eV Fe 2p1/2 and Fe 2p3/2 respectively [43]. The Fe 2p3/2 peak can be further split into doublets attributed to Fe3+ and Fe2+ oxidation but Fe 2p1/2 exhibits only one peak for Fe3+ which is commonly observed in case of many ferrites. The C1s spectrum (Fig. 3e) can be deconvoluted into three peaks at 284.8, 286.2 and 287.3 eV corresponding to graphitic (C-C), epoxy/hydroxyl (C-O) and carbonyl (C=O) respectively corresponding to GO/RGO [44]. The high intensity C-C and low intensity C-O and C=O peaks confirm the maximum reduction of GO to RGO. For O 1s spectrum (Fig. 3f), the main peak located at 531.5 eV is assigned to the lattice oxygen, while the peak at 532.9 eV is related to the hydroxyl groups. It has been reported in several works that positive or negative shifts in binding energies is attributed to changes in surface charge density due to transfer of charge carriers between
semiconductors with different fermi levels [45]. The positive shift in binding energy of Ag 3d5/2 as per literature [34] hints at electron transfer from BFO which increases the electron density. This is also supported by negative moving of binding energies of Bi 4f as reported in literature [46] for bare BFO. The shifts and no-shifts in binding energies are attributed to interactions. All the changes and no-changes observed in the binding energies are attributed to the interactions between semiconductors and their favourable positioning as desired. Thus XPS findings imply the existence of ABR junction. Fig. 4(a) and (b) shows the SEM images of ACO and BFO nanoparticles respectively. BFO acquires a nano-flower like uniform morphology while ACO posessses spherical shape. The deposition of Ag on ACO can be observed in Ag/ACO SEM image (Fig. 4b inset). The micrographs for morphology analysis of of ABR-8 at different magnifications are provided in Fig. 4(c-e). It can be observed in low resolution
SEM images that ACO and BFO are in contact with each other and disperesd over RGO which has sheet like morphology. High resolution SEM image (Fig. 4e) clearly shows that morphologies of ACO and BFO has not changed on formation of the junction. The corresponding elemental mapping spatial distribution for ABR-8 and relative abundance of individual elements is represented in in Fig. 4(f-l). For detailed morphologies and microstructural analysis TEM and HRTEM was also performed./ TEM analysis was further performed conducted to
elucidate micromorphology and nanostructure anslysis. In Fig. 5(b) Ag/ACO and BFO particles can be easily seen with a high interfacial contact. In addtion HRTEM image (Fig. 5c) confirm the flower like BFO and spherical ACO with small sized metallic nano-Ag. The corresponding interfacical contact and lattice fringes are further confirmed by HR-TEM analysis. In Fig. 5 (d) the lattice spacings of

This also confirms high crystallinity (SAED pattern Fig. 5d inset) and high interfacial contact between semiconductors and Ag. This type of structure is favorable for electron transfer and mobility which surely can lead to high photocatalytic performance.

sections.heading: 3.2. Optical and electrochemical response
sections.text:
The light absorption potential of ACO, BFO, ACO/BFO, AB-5, AB-10, AB-15, ABR-5, ABR-8 and ABR-11 was assesed by recording UV/vis diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) test resuts were compared in Fig. 6(a). Both the semiconductors Ag2CrO4 and BiFeO3 show high absorption in visible with higher for former. Ag2CrO4 generally absorption edge lies between 545 and 750 nm and in this case it lies at 740 nm [47]. BiFeO3 absorbs in visible region with absorption edge near 550 nm however there is a red shift observed on addition of ACO (10%) i.e. ACO/BFO along with higher visible absorption However when ACO/Ag is added to BFO, in addition to higher visible response, absorption in NIR region is also observed. This is due to formation of heterojunction between the two and surface plasmon resonance effect of metallic Ag nanoparticles. It has been well established by varius similar experiments that optical performance of a heterojunction can be effieicently enhanced by surface modification (obtained by photo-deposition in this case) using metals as Ag to induce plasmonic effect. The junction thus obtained shows intense absorption in visible region because of localized surface plasmon resonance [48]. As the SPR effect originates from the mutual oscillations of free electrons of metallic Ag nanoparticles under incident photons especially visible which not only enhances the visible absorption but also extends the spectrum capture to NIR region. In addition the dark coloured Ag nanopaticles absorb higher visible light with a strong SPR effect [49] (plasmonic absorption shown in Fig. 6a). Besides this Ag acts as a solid mediator for electrons in the Z-scheme catalytic system and helps in transfer of photogenerated electrons from conduction band of Ag2CrO4. On the other hand it also acts as co-catalyst capturing electrons from CB of BiFeO3 as observed in other experiments too [50]. Comparing with Ag2CrO4 the other catalysts obtained by photoreduction of Ag, show higher SPR effect and absorption in NIR
region as well due to absence or lower amount of Ag0 in Ag2CrO4 as compared to other photocatalysts i.e ABR series. The band gaps as calculated from tauc’s relation [51] (Fig. 6b and Fig. S2c) are 1.70, 2.43, 2.28, 2.01, 1.92, 2.08, 1.94 and 1.82 eV for ACO, BFO, AB-5, AB-10 ,AB-15, ABR-5, ABR-8 and ABR-11 respectively. The absorption edge of ABR series shows absorption edge shifting towards longer wavelength which shows that incorporation of RGO can enhance the light absorption and plays an important role in the migration of photo-generated electrons. The Mott-schottky plots (Fig. S2) were obtained for BFO and ACO under 750 Hz for maesuring the flat band potentials. The positive slope for both the semiconductors reveal that n-type materials. For a amjority of semicnductors, the top of valence band (VB) potential for lies between 0.10 and 0.30 eV and can be taken as 0.20 eV for calculating CB positions [52]. The flat band potentials for ACO and BFO were calculated as 1.00 eV and −0.15 eV (vs NHE at pH=7) respectively. Thus as calculated conduction bands (ECB) are 0.90 eV (ACO) and −0.35 eV (BFO). The VB potentials for ACO and BFO are estimated as 2.50 eV and 2.08 eV respectively. The band gap parameters are listed in Table S1. The charge separation efficiency of synthesized junctions was also tested by Photo-luminescence (PL) spectroscopy (Fig. 6c). Due to lower band gaps of ACO and BFO the recombination is higher and so PL intensity is highest. After the formation of junction ACO/BFO the recombination is reduced due to efficient transfer of electrons and holes. In case of AB-10 the metallic silver facilitates the electrons flow to further reduce recombination. In addition inclusion of RGO further facilitates the electrons flow. Hence ABR-8 shows lowest PL intensity. Fig. 6(d) shows electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) Nyquist plots for the photocatalysts to assess the electron transfer capacity. A high transfer of electrons along the interface of semiconductors leads to impedance reduction. A noticeable change in the electrochemical impedance is an indicator of the junction interfacial properties [53]. ABR-8 shows the lowest radius arc which means it possesses best electron transfer and flow and thus lowest resistance. Single and binary
junctions show high radius for plots which show they have poor separation and transfer ability as compared to ABR junction. The photo-electrochemical measurements were further made to support above observations. Fig. 6(e) displays transient on-off photocurrent response (PCR) plots of various photocatalysts for 5 cycles under visible light exposure. ABR-8 shows highest photocurrent response because of best charge separation, quantum efficiency, facilitation of flow of electrons by RGO and surface plasmon response from metallic silver. A minor and gradual decrease in photocurrent is observed which may be a consequence of slow detachment of sample from ITO glass may be after sometime. Thus UV-DRS, PL, EIS and PCR results show that ABR-8 is the best catalyst in terms of optical and photoelectrochemical response in addition to reduced recombination and higher interfacial transfer. Fig. 6(f) shows the specific surface area measurements for binary AB-10 and ternary AB-8 junctions obtained by N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm analysis. Both the junctions exhibit type-IV adsorption isotherm with a porous morphology. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas for AB-10 and ABR-8 are 43.4 m2/g and 62.3m2/g respectively. AB-10 shows a pore volume of 0.127 cm3/g while for ABR-8 the pore volume is 0.175 cm3/g. The higher surface area of ABR-8 will facilitate higher adsorption sites for pollutant along with more active sites for photocatalytic reactions [54]. The vibrating sample magnetometry studies (VSM) were performed to assess the magnetic character of photocatalyst ABR-8. The magnetism –hysteresis (M-H) plot for ABR8 (Fig. S3) shows that it possesses a typical ferromagnetic character with magnetisation of 35.2 emu/g, which is enough for magnetic separation.

sections.heading: 3.3. Photocatalytic bromate reduction and CIF degradation
3.3.1. Optimization of BiFeO3 and Ag2CrO4 ratio
sections.text:
For effective wide spectral photocatalytic performance Ag2CrO4/ BiFeO3 heterojunction was formed to overcome shortcomings of single catalysts. However for fabricating an efficient junction we need to optimize the ratios of two semiconductors and then analyse their optical response and photocatalytic activity. Firstly the ratio of ACO to BFO (5,
10, 15 wt% ACO) was optimized and best optical and electrochemical response was shown by ACO/BFO (10wt% ACO). After the catalyst is exposed to Xe lamp for photo-deposition of metallic Ag without altering the ACO content AB-10 (10 wt% Ag/ACO) shows the best response as far as properties required for photocatalysis is concerned. AB-10 catalyst was then utilized for ABR formation by varying RGO content (5, 8, 11 wt%). Thus ABR-8 was found to have high optical response in UV, visible and NIR region in addition to highest charge separation and lowest recombination. The preliminary bromate reduction and CO2 reduction experiments were performed (Figs. S4 and S5) under visible light (380–780 nm). Among the junctions AB-10 showed highest reduction BrO3− from 500μgL−1 to 50.2 μgL−1 while the performance decreases for AB-15. This is because excessive loading of ACO may hinder the light absorption of BFO which forms major part of the junction. However in case of ternary junction ABR-8 shows the highest performance (Fig. 7a) and reduces bromate concentration to 2.4 μgL−1 in 90min. Owing to a higher surface area (BET measurements) surface area more bromate ions can be adsorbed on its surface which are reduced by electrons as RGO also acts as electron storage and facilitator. Similar behaviour is observed for CO2 reduction where 71.4 μmol g−1 CH4 was evolved in 8 h in presence of AB-10. However, the trend is different for ternary junction- ABR-11 > ABR-8 > ABR-5. This is because for effective CO2 reduction adsorption of CO2 on to the catalyst is the key step and RGO provides these sites for better reduction.

sections.heading: 3.3.2. Photocatalytic BrO3− reduction
sections.text:
Fig. 7(a) shows the time profile for photo-reduction of BrO3− ions under visible light irradiation in presence of synthesized catalysts. The bromate concentration decreases with increasing time in presence of each catalyst. For pure BFO, BrO3− concentration decreased from 500 μg L−1 to 172 μg L−1 in 90min, the activity is increased on inclusion of ACO in AB-10 (reduced to 50.22 μg L−1). However in presence of ABR-8 the [BrO3−] reduces to 2.4 μg L−1 which means that 99.6% was reduced in 90min and 96.4% in just 60min. However on increasing the content of RGO to 11% (ABR-11) the reduction fell down to a little extent because at higher content redundant RGO may act as a recombination centre. The reduction order follows: ABR > AB >
ACO/BFO > BFO. This clearly indicated that both Ag and RGO have joint effect which leads to better performance. RGO provides high surface area for adsorption of bromate ions helps in electron storage & facilitates movement. Metallic Ag0 shows high visible absorption due to SPR effect and in addition is a mediator as under visible light it produced electrons which further expedite the reduction. The general scheme of bromate reduction is given in Scheme 1. The overall photo-reduction follows pseudo first order kinetics (Fig. 7b). The apparent first-order reaction rate constant (kapp) of bromate degradation was 0.072min−1 with ABR-8 which was ≈ 3 times that of AB-10 and 6 times than bare BFO. Fig. 7(c) shows the removal efficiency of BrO3− ions at different pH with ABR-8 under visible light. The photo-reduction was promoted when pH was increased from acidic (3) to neutral (6.8- working pH). However it again decreased when pH is increased to basic (9–11). The pzc of ABR-8 is 7.4 and at pH=6.8 the surface is positively charged or slightly neutral favouring adsorption of BrO3− ions. However at higher pH the surface is negatively charged too leading to repulsions which decreases the photo-reduction process. The reduction process in acidic pH should be favoured as it leads to protonation of functional groups which attracts bromate ions. However it is observed for slightly acidic pH as at very high acidic conditions the electrons are lost and may generate reactive oxygen species which cause oxidation of Br− ions to BrO3− ions again [55]. The existing cations and anions in water can affect the photoreduction of BrO3− ions. The concentrations of ions used are representative of municipal tap water. The reduction was tested with ABR-8 in presence of various ions and results are presented in Fig. 7(d). It can be observed that Ca2+ and Mg2+ ions do not have any detrimental effect on bromate removal. As far as anions are concerned Cl− has no effect on the bromate reduction. However presence of NO3– ions inhibits the BrO3− ions removal because nitrate ions have capacity to scavenge electrons and get reduced. In presence of HCO3– ions the reduction falls but to a lesser extent than NO3– because in case of former the competition between BrO3− and HCO3– ions for adsorption slows down the reaction. To ascertain the role of electrons in photo-reduction process variable concentration of K2S2O8 (2 & 6mM) a quencher for electrons was added into reaction in presence of ABR-8. Electrons react with S2O82− ions almost twice the rate of BrO3− ions [56]. Thus rate of removal falls which further falls with increase in K2S2O8 concentration which confirms the photocatalytic reduction via photo-generated electrons. The photocatalytic reduction of BrO3− ions was also tested under municipal tap water and distilled water with visible light for understanding the effect of water matrix (Fig. 7e). The tap water parameters are given in Table 1. Without any catalyst we hardly achieve any reduction of bromate ions both in tap water and distilled water. ABR-8 exhibits excellent photo-reduction under both sources of water with an inhibition to some extent in case of tap water which is due to presence of NO3– and SO42− ions. ABR-8 has desirable photo-reduction capabilities in natural water also. As ABR-8 shows absorption in UV, visible and NIR region, so the photo-reduction of BrO3− was also tested under these sources including natural solar light and results are presented in Fig. 7(f). The order of performance is UV > Visible > Solar > NIR. In presence of UV light almost complete removal is observed in less than 45min. Under natural sunlight the 79.5% of BrO3− ions were removed which shows that ABR-8 is capable of working under natural conditions. Though a very small reduction is achieved under NIR light, however the catalyst is active in this region too which confirms the wide spectral applications.

sections.heading: 3.3.3. Photocatalytic ciprofloxacin degradation
sections.text:
The photocatalytic degradation of ciprofloxacin (CIF) was tested under UV, visible, solar and NIR light for confirming the wide spectral activity. However the detailed reaction parameters analysis was performed under visible light. The degradation efficiencies of BFO, ACO/ BFO, AB-5, AB-10, AB-15, ABR-5, ABR-8 and ABR-11 and
corresponding kinetics plots under visible light irradiation are shown in Fig. 8(a) and (b) respectively. ABR-8 shows highest CIF degradation of 96.2% in 90min of irradiation followed by ABR-11 (89.4%). Single catalyst BFO shows just 37.8% CIF removal which improves to 46.6% on inclusion of 10 wt% ACO (ACO/BFO). However the performance is further improved when we use Xe exposure during synthesis to produce ACO/Ag/BFO. Thus AB-10 (10 wt% Ag/ACO) shows 64.5% degradation because of metallic Ag showing high visible absorption due to SPR effect. The inclusion of RGO increases reaction manifold because of dual characteristics of adsorption and electron facilitator. On moving from single BFO to ACO, CIF degradation improves because of formation of junction which improves the electrons flow and reduces the recombination. ABR-8 shows highest photocurrent response and lowest recombination (evident from PCR, EIS and PL results), which is also demonstrated in photocatalytic performance. The mesoporous structure high specific surface area (owing to presence of RGO) of ABR-8 heterostructure provides abundant active sites for adsorbing more CIF molecules on its surface leading to enhancement of photo-degradation. The reactivity order follows: ABR-8 > ABR-11 > ABR-5 > AB10 > AB-15 > AB-5 > ACO/BFO > BFO. The corresponding kinetic plots are provided in Fig. 8(b) showing a pseudo first order fitting. The apparent rate constants are highest for ABR-8 (0.0638min−1) which is almost 5 fold faster than AB-10 (0.0131min−1) and 7 times than BFO (0.0092min−1). The photo-degradation of drugs depends on the initial pH of the solution and the pzc of the photocatalyst as these are pH sensitive. CIF is an amphoteric drug with two pKa values of 6.09 (for –COOH group) and 8.74 (for nitrogen on the piperazinyl ring) with isoelectric point at pH=7.4 [13]. The effect of pH onto CIF photodegradation was studied in presence of ABR-8 under visible light (Fig. S6). The degradation is strongly inhibited at highly acidic and basic pH. The degradation decreases from 96.2% (pH=6.8) to 22.4% at pH=4 and 31.2% at pH=11. At pH=6.8 the surface of catalyst is positive due to protonation of functional groups while drug is slightly negatively charged (–COO− group) or neutral for a better interaction and adsorption thereof. At lower pH, CIF is protonated so the photocatalyst leading to repulsions and poor interactions between the two. Similarly at higher pH both the pollutant and ABR-8 are negatively charged leading to decreased interactions. Besides this in alkaline medium the generation of ●OH radicals is inhibited. Thus best results are obtained in pH range 6–7. Figure S7 shows degradation of CIF in presence of common electrolytes NO3–, Cl− , SO42− and HCO3– ions. It was observed that CIP degradation is not influenced by Cl− ions but results displayed decreasing trends on addition of HCO3– and SO42− which is derived from enhanced screening because of increased negative charges. However HCO3– ions decrease degradation to a larger extent because they react with •OH to form lesser reactive ●CO3– [57]. A slight positive increase in degradation was observed for NO3– ions as they produce ●OH radicals under visible light [58]. To assess the wide spectral degradation potential of ABR-8 the tests were performed under UV, visible, NIR and natural sunlight represented in Fig. 8(c). The performance and rate constants are listed in table 2. The rate is highest in case of UV exposure with rate constant 0.0884min−1 which is obvious due to high energy of UV light. The degradation rare however falls in case of solar light (0.0471min−1) and this obvious decrease can be owed to lower energy of natural solar

light. The rate further falls in NIR region however it can be seen that the catalyst shows some degradation ability in near infra-red light. Thus ABR-8 can be used to efficiently degrade various pollutants in broad spectrum of light including solar light which shows its potential in practical situation. The change in water matrix to tap water leads to a small fall in the degradation which is obviously due to some anions inhibiting the degradation by consuming radicals (Fig. S8). However the fall is incremental showing that catalyst can be used in real water systems efficiently. ABR-8 possesses ferromagnetic character with enough magnetisation for magnetic separation and thus catalyst was successfully
separated form solution for reuse. In order to confirm the that secondary pollution is avoided separation experiments were also made as reported in some previous works [59]. Figure S9 shows that ABR-8 is separated and recovered under magnetic field of 120 mT. The plot shows absorbance as a function of time and reports that change in concentration of catalyst dispersion is ascertained by comparing absorbance at different times. For elucidation of degradation pathway of CIF, LC-MS of degradation products was performed after 5min and 30min of degradation reaction in presence of ABR-8 under visible light (Fig. S10). It can be observed that by-products may be produced by attack of reactive
oxygen species (●OH and ●O2–) at specific sites i.e quinolone moiety and piperazine ring [60]. After 5min LC-MS the initial peak of CIF at m/z=332.3 which is almost diminished in spectrum obtained after 30min of degradation experiment which shows that CIF molecule is getting decomposed [47]. The various steps involved are oxidation- dehalogenation- decarboxylation-hydroxylation. The intermediates and by-products detected are listed in Table S2. The first pathway begins with hydroxylation which may increase the weight as observed in detected by-products BP1 (m/ z=351.1), BP-2 (m/z=381), BP-3 (m/z=348) and BP-4 (m/z=383) which was also observed in previous experiments [61]. The hydroxylation has many pathways e.g. C-12 in piperazine ring is a suitable position because of presence of N-11 which is susceptible to attack which is also observed in mechanism given in Scheme 2. Secondly by other pathway involves rupture of piperazine ring by attack of radicals to obtain hemiacetals. This leads to formation of BP-8 (m/z=306) (by dealkylation) and further attack leads to BP-7 (m/
z=279). The BP-7 can also be formed by hydroxylation of quinolone moiety followed by hydrolysis. Further dehydroxylation of BP-7 forms BP-9 (m/z=263) and subsequent ring rupture and decarboxylation forms BP-10 (m/z=192). In this manner subsequent radicals attack can lead to formation of simpler aliphatic moieties and CO2 and H2O. Fig. 8(d) shows the mineralization rate or total organic carbon (TOC) removal rate for ABR-8 mediated CIF degradation under UV, visible and solar light. ABR-8 shows 92%, 85% and 71% TOC removal under UV, visible and sunlight after 2 h. The higher TOC removal suggests higher mineralization capabilities. Fig. 8d (inset) shows comparison of rate constants for CIF degradation with ABR-8 and shows rate is manifolds higher than other binary and single catalysts. The catalyst was also used for continuous 5 cycles of CIF degradation (Fig. S11) with no appreciable fall in the performance. This proves the efficiency and stability of ABR-8 catalyst. To study the role of active species (●OH and ●O2–) involved scavenging studies were performed (Fig. 8e). The degradation is
quenched by addition of IPA and BQ suggesting active role of both hydroxyl radicals and superoxide anion radicals. However IPA quenches the rate to a greater extent which hints the higher participation. This was further validated by ESR spin trapping was used and results are presented in Fig. 8(f). The ESR signals for DMPO-●O2– are comparatively weaker than DMPO-●OH confirming that ●OH are more prevalent in reaction mixture. The detailed mechanism is discussed in further sections.

sections.heading: 3.3.4. Photocatalytic CO2 reduction
sections.text:
The photocatalytic reduction of CO2 with H2O of as prepared photocatalysts was assessed under visible light first (380–780 nm). Major products detected were CH4 and CO2 and CH3OH was detected in traces. To ensure that these products come from CO2 feedstock, blank experiments were performed with no light irradiation, with no catalyst and in presence of Ar gas. No products were detected which confirm that CO and CH4 are evolved from CO2 and H2O mixture. The accumulation yields of CH4 and CO in 8 h of visible light irradiation are given in Fig. 9(a) and (b). It can be observed that CH4 is formed to a higher extent than CO. Many experiments have reported that hydrogen evolution via water splitting and CO2 reduction generally and more often compete with each other during photocatalytic reactions [62]. However very low concentration of hydrogen evolved cannot be detected by gas chromatography. Alternatively protons or hydrogen radicals formed could be consumed by intermediates produced by CO2 photo-reduction i.e CO, CH4, CH3OH etc. In this case no H2 was detected so CO2 reduction was the major reaction involved here. Negligible yield of products is obtained in presence of bare BFO and ACO. The best yield of CH4 is obtained on ABR-11 was 180 μmol g−1 followed by ABR-8 (131 μmol g−1) after 8 h illumination. For binary junctions AB-10 shows highest yield of 71 μmol g−1 which decreases then for AB-15. The CH4 yield was significantly enhanced with increase in presence of Ag/ACO because of better visible performance and generation of electrons by SPR effect. With increase in Ag/ACO content the effective heterojunction performs better with a better flow of electrons and highly reduced recombination. In a similar fashion
increasing content of RGO in ABR junction, CH4 yields increases manifold because functionality on RGO leads to higher CO2 adsorption which is then reduced by photo-generated electrons. The second product obtained is CO and for it also ABR-11 shows highest evolution of 38 μmol g−1. The higher conversion ability of ABR-11 catalysts is due to a higher optical response, dispersion of catalysts onto RGO matrix, better CO2 adsorption, electron-mediation by RGO and electron facilitation by metallic Ag. Both Ag and RGO are required for this excellent performance as these trigger the reduction process by suitable management and production of electrons.The photo-reduction of CO2 was also tested under alkali activation by performing experiments in 0.2M NaOH solution rather than distilled water. Fig. 9(c) shows time course accumulated CH4 evolution under alkali activation. The CH4 evolution was increased for each catalyst with 242 μmol g−1 for ABR-11. The increase in CO2 conversion to CH4 by addition of NaOH is due to two reasons– Firstly it forms carbonates which increases the CO2 solubility and secondly a slightly basic medium also favours formation of hydroxyl radicals. The radicals thus generated lead to higher separation of electrons from holes and higher reduction is thus achieved [63]. It was observed that in this experiment ABR catalyst is selective for CH4 production from CO2. Fig. 9(d) shows the selectivity of ABR-11 and AB-10 for CH4 and CO. It can be analysed that ABR-11 is more selective to CH4 than CO in comparison to binary junction AB-10. The detailed explanations for mechanisms are discussed in subsequent section. The photocatalytic CO2 conversion was also tested under UV, visible, NIR and sunlight too and results are presented in Fig. 9(e). Highest CH4 evolution of 242 μmol g−1 was achieved under UV light. However the conversion falls under solar light which is obvious for lower energy solar light as compared to UV and pure visible light. CH4 evolution is also detected under NIR light. Long term experiments were performed for investigating the stability and recycling efficiency of ABR-11 for 5 continuous cycles (Fig. 9f). For first three cycles same catalyst was used without washing and fall in the efficiency was observed owing to blocking of active sites. However after magnetic recovery and washings the catalyst was recovered and we observe a rejuvenating effect on the conversion performance for last two cycles.

sections.heading: 3.3.5. Photocatalytic mechanism
sections.text:
A photocatalytic mechanism can be predicted for BrO3− removal CIF degradation the basis of optical response, photo-electrochemical properties, photo-luminescence studies. As far as BrO3− reduction to Br− is concerned photogenerated electrons bring out the reduction. This has been in this experiment earlier confirmed by addition of S2O82– as electron scavenger and marker to analyse role of electrons in reduction process. The test results here also support the fact that electrons prefer to react with S2O82− ions than bromate ions. Accepting this fact the catalyst with highest charge separation and electron flow across the interface will be best in reducing the bromate ions. ABR-8 has the lowest recombination and charge separation and shows excellent activity under visible, UV and natural solar light. In addition under visible light metallic Ag also acts as a source of electrons which further accelerated the reduction. On the other hand due to low band gap ACO and BFO have high recombination of electron-holes and so poor reduction activity. Secondly to assess the role of and contribution of various reactive oxygen species in the degradation of CIF, scavenging experiments and ESR measurements were made (Fig. 8e and f). As explained earlier both scavenging and ESR measurements confirm that major active species are ●OH radicals with some participation from ●O2– too. Comparing to ESR spectrum obtained for CIF degradation by binary junction (ACO/ BFO) i.e. without metallic Ag0 (Fig. S12) we observe that the intensity of DMPO-●O2– are much weaker than DMPO-●OH. However the intensity of ●O2– increases in case of ABR (ACO/Ag/BFO@RGO) without any fall in the intensity of hydroxyl radicals. This shows that metallic Ag and RGO can contribute in generation of ●O2– radicals. Now under visible light illumination both ACO and BFO produce electron-hole pairs due to their low band gap. As depicted in Fig. 10 the photogenerated electrons can transfer from CB of BFO (−0.35 eV) to that of ACO (0.80 eV) which is highly positive as compared to that of BFO. Similarly the holes from VB of ACO (2.5 eV) can migrate to lesser positive VB of BFO (2.08 eV). In this way a double transfer can separate the electron-hole pairs for effective generation of radicals. However this may be true for ACO/BFO junction without metallic Ag. However in case of AB series (ACO/Ag/BFO) the metallic Ag plays an important role. Firstly metallic nano-Ag particles can capture electrons from surface and thus contribute in reducing recombination. Secondly under visible or solar light they can donate electrons for Under UV light a strong signal of ●O2– is observed along with a weak signal of ●OH. Under visible light irradiation a high intensity ESR signal of ●O2– is still obtained and the intensity of ●OH is increased considerably. Thus with incorporation of Ag/Fe3O4 the generation of •O2– and •OH radicals is enhanced considerably. This is also supported form ESR measurements. A double charge transfer mechanism is converted into an effective Zscheme on inclusion of Ag0. On the basis of these findings a logical explanation can be made for enhanced CIF degradation performance of ABR catalyst. As per ESR measurements both hydroxyl radicals and superoxide anion radicals are present with former in excess. The redox potential of E (O2/●O2–)=−0.33 eV) [64] and only CB edge of BFO is negative enough to oxidize O2 to •O2–. Hydroxyl radicals can be generated via H2O and –OH. The redox potential of E (●OH/H2O) is 2.27 eV vs NHE and VB edge of ACO is positive enough for oxidizing water into hydroxyl radicals. Similarly ●OH radicals can’t be generated on VB of BFO by oxidation of water but can be generated from – ions as E (●OH/–OH) is 1.99 eV vs NHE [65]. But when holes migrate from VB of ACO to that of
BFO they lose their potential to oxidize water for generating OH radicals. But ESR measurements show that OH radicals are present in excess. Thus these radicals may be formed by an alternative route i.e via –OH ions and through reaction of ●O2– and H+. For ABR catalyst Ag0 nanoparticles can absorb visible light and produce electrons-hole pairs via SPR [66] and these get transferred to ACO and BFO for further formation of radicals. The electrons can also be transferred from CB of ACO and BFO to RGO with help of Ag as transporter or mediator. Thus the photo-generated electrons and holes are formed and effectively transported for a higher generation of radicals. Owing to large surface area and functionality of RGO more CIF molecules are adsorbed on its surface and react with trapped radicals, electrons and holes. Thirdly for photo-reduction of CO2 into CH4 and CO is facilitated by photo-generated electrons. Table 3 shows the reactions involved in generation of CO and CH4 and performance of ABR-11, AB-10 and BFO. Poor adsorption potential of binary junction is an important reason for poor photoreduction capability. It has already been inferred in earlier sections that ABR follows a Z-scheme mechanism for photocatalytic reactions with metallic Ag0 acting as a mediator. Under visible light both ACO and BFO are activated to form electron-hole pairs. The polarisation effect of Ag/Ag2CrO4 may affect the charge density on metallic Ag leading to formation of some partial positive and negative charges on surface as observed in previous works [67]. This may behave as a centre for recombination. As electrons are flowing from CB of ACO to Ag0 surface and elevates the fermi level of metallic Ag. The holes from VB of BFO may move to Ag0 (in contact with ACO) and recombine with electrons coming from ACO to neutralize the polarisation and thus leads to separation. Thus it leads to separation of electrons in CB of BFO and holes in VB of ACO. The CB potential of BFO (-0.35 eV) is more negative than that of ACO and VB potential of ACO is more positive than BFO. Energetic protons may be generated at VB of ACO via water oxidation and these react with electrons received from CB of BFO to produce CH4 from CO2. As we have already reported that CH4 is generated as a selective product as compared to CO. If we observe Scheme 3 then generation of CH4 is a multi-step reaction passing through formation of many intermediates. In addition CH4 evolution is an 8e−/8H+ reaction and may progress by multiple proton-coupled electron transfer in a single step for selective CH4 product [68]. Secondly it can be explained in another way that because of presence of RGO basic characteristics are induced on surface of ABR catalyst as pzc is 7.4, CO2 adsorption and hydrogenation is favoured. Ag on the surface also captures the electrons and boosts the separation. Also the bridging of Ag in the effective Z-scheme junction leads to stay of electrons in highly negative CB of BFO and holes at highly positive VB of ACO. Thus it leads to protection of the potentials for effective 8e mediated selective reduction to CH4. As conversion of CO2 into CO is a 2e− step and should be the favoured product. The redox potential for CH4/CO2 is −0.24 eV and for CO/CO2 is −0.42 eV. The electrons in CB of BFO have enough negative potential for reducing CO2 to CH4 which is also favoured by multi electron transfer in single step by proton coupling. On the other hand CB potential of BFO is not enough negative for single step conversion of CO2 into methanol. Similar CH4 selectivity was observed in case of CO2 photo-reduction CdS/ BiVO4 Z-scheme heterojunction [17]. The higher yields of CH4 were attributed to shorter electron diffusion length of thinner BiVO4 which leads to more generation of electrons on exposure. With increasing time the electron density on CB of CdS increases and favours CH4 formation in long run experiments. Under alkali activation Rather et al
photocatalytic CH4 formation rate of 205 μmol g−1h−1 with 100% selectivity was achieved using g-C3N4/Ag/AgCl/BiVO4 [63]. They claimed that multi-electron and proton transfer by proton-coupledelectron-transfer (PCET) mechanism is possible. In addition due to alkali activation carbonate species are formed which get adsorbed into photocatalyst and increase solubility of CO2. In another experiment 18.5 μmol g−1 h−1 CH4 was evolved by gaseous reduction of CO2 in presence of AuPd/3DOM-TiO2 [69], though higher selectivity was observed here. Considering the photo-reduction and photo-oxidative capabilities, ABR series of photocatalysts perform excellent over wide spectrum of light. In addition to the effective formation of a Z-scheme junction utilizing BiFeO3 with low optimized content of Ag2CrO4, the triggering effect of metallic Ag and RGO leads to higher reduction of bromate ion, CIF degradation and selective CH4 formation from CO2 photo-reduction. The protection of high potential CB and VB from BFO and ACO respectively by Ag by electron transfer and donation by SPR under visible light leads to higher formation of radicals as well as facilitation of 8e−/8h+ CH4 production. In addition RGO provides high surface area, active sites and participates in electron transfer and transportation. In summary a Z-scheme mechanism is active for high photo-activity of ABR junction. In addition to role of semiconductors in the charge separation, Ag and RGO lead to a triggering effect both for oxidation and reduction applications.

sections.heading: 3.4. Stability and reusability
sections.text: It has already been discussed in earlier sections that ABR catalyst is magnetically recoverable and reusable in photo-reduction and photooxidation reactions for many cycles. The stability and reusability are two most important factors for practical applications of the photocatalysts. Magnetic recovery tests show that catalyst is easy to separate and recover. To confirm this XPS scan, FTIR and SEM analysis of ABR-8 sample was performed after 5 cycles of CIF photodegradation under visible light. The FTIR spectrum of ABR-8 before and after reuse is given in Fig. S13. The peak at 865 cm−1 correspond to Cr-O stretching in ACO [70]. Two strong absorptive peaks around 510 cm−1 and 430 cm−1 are attributed to the Fe-O stretching and O-Fe-O bending vibrations, being characteristics of the octahedral FeO6 groups in the perovskite compounds [71]. Most of corresponding peaks of graphene oxide are either diminished or vanished confirming formation of reduced graphene oxide in the junction. There are no abnormal changes in the FTIR spectrum of catalyst after reuse. Similarly the XPS survey scan of ABR-8 after reuse (Fig. S14) has not changed accepts for some minor intensity changes. The SEM image of ABR-8 before and after use (Fig. S15) show no abnormal or noticeable changes which shows catalyst has a high stability and durability.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text: In summary Ag2CrO4/Ag/BiFeO3 and Ag2CrO4/Ag/BiFeO3@RGO (ABR) heterojunctions were fabricated by optimisation for best optical response. These catalysts adopt well defined structure and uniformity with semiconductor junction dispersed well onto RGO matrix ensuring a high interfacial contact. The catalyst ABR shows a high light harvesting efficiency with capability to work in wide spectrum including NIR and sunlight owing to better charge flow and separation. An exposure of Xe lamp for photodeposition of some amount of silver in ordinary ACO/BFO junction leads to multi-fold rise in photocatalytic performance. Almost complete removal of BrO3− ions under visible light in less than 90min and 96.2% CIF removal shows the excellent photo-reduction and photo-oxidation capabilities of the ABR junction. LC-MS was performed for predicting CIF degradation pathway: dehalogenation, hydroxylation, decarboxylation and dihydroxylation followed by hydrolysis. Scavenging experiments and ESR measurements leads to predict a suitable photocatalytic mechanism for bromate reduction CIF degradation and photo-reduction of CO2 into CH4. Incorporation of metallic Ag into ACO/BFO junction transfers ordinary double charge transfer mechanism to a highly efficient Zscheme. Metallic Ag and RGO both favour multi-electron single step proton coupled CH4 formation, BrO3− reduction and ●OH and ●O2– radical generation for CIF degradation. The electron capture by Ag0, electron donation by SPR, adsorption potential and electron mediation of RGO leads to a triggering effect in Z-scheme photocatalyst. ABR heterojunction with a broad spectral response and multi-pollutant removal capacity by photo-reduction-oxidation capability helps in understanding in rational designing of Z-scheme catalysts.
